title: >>> The TOMS RIVER TOURNAMENT
body_text:
"I don't even know where to begin really. A surreal night, one unlike any other. This tournament brought out feelings in me only comparable to the ten-events. After all was said and done, you come away with more than just a trophy, but friends for the rest of your life. For 5 hours, life's roadblocks cease to exist."
- JOHN TRONOLONE
-- 52 teams, 1 goal: win the first-ever Toms River Tournament. Double Elimination!
Pretty simple right? WRONG.
The chills run up your spine, the hair on your neck stands up, the adrenaline pumps ...
You're probably getting those very feelings just thinking about it.
The R.A.T.S.
Formed in just 4 short days, co-captained by the dominant female duo Sara DeCuir and Diana DiBuccio,
The R.A.T.S.
were ready, willing, and able to come out on top in this massive 52-team war.
Cap.
Sara DeCuir
Cap.
Diana DiBuccio
Mike Edwards
Derek Carty [not pictured]
Alison Bertsch
Mike Butler
Sascha Basista
Jack Mess
Lenny Herrera
Joey Smalls*.
*
Replaced Grant Cornero, who was unable to attend due to a conflicting work schedule
.
The first round match-up turned out to be a show-stealer. It wasn't easy however as one-by-one,
The R.A.T.S.
were disposed of, leaving Sascha Basista fighting against a pack of wolves - alone. But just when things looked grim, the dodging specialties in young Basista began to come out, with all ears and eyes positioned on Court 2. With the crowd solidly behind him, Sascha fended off a good number of opponents before going down. Much credit deserved to the young lion who was greeted by a well-deserved ovation upon returning to the stands.
With one loss already recorded, winning this next match would decide the fate of
The R.A.T.S.
Unfortuantely, Round 2 mirrored that of their first encounter, as within 3 minutes, Derek Carty and Mike Butler were all that remained of the red and black attack. Once Derek went down, it was all up to Butler who has proven time and again to be a top dog. After a gutsy effort, Butler was taken out by the relentless onslaught of his opponents.
A terrific, fearless showing for
The R.A.T.S.
as a team that faced adversity before gametime made an impact the only way they know how. None of the team members have anything to be ashamed of.
The O.R.P. Knights
An all-star team, co-captained by Ryan McCrorey and Mike "Sputz" Krott, with one purpose ... to win.
Cap.
Ryan McCrorey
Cap.
Mike "Sputz" Krott
Chris Burke
Justin Pierce
Kevin Adams
Kevin Fitzpatrick
John Tronolone
Chris Adams
Kevin Megill Jr.
Tom Adams
Smaller boundries, softer painball-sized dodge balls, among pages and pages of rules unaccustomed to the weekly dodgeball fan created heavy turmoil before the getgo. But despite being taken out of their element, the
O.R.P. Knights
were nothing short of dominant.
The initial round witnessed an impressive showing from one Tom Adams, eliminating 40% of his opposition, a game that eventually ended with a lucky footshot from John Tronolone. The
O.R.P. Knights
were moving up the ladder of success.
One after another, the
Knights
looked unstoppable, defeating the tourny's best sqauds. Though eliminations came fast and furious, through it all, the group remained strong. The brackets became increasingly smaller, with the
Knights
still on the board.
Come the fourth and fifth rounds, the butterflies remained, each match becoming more crucial than the last. But somehow, especially with expertise of the legendary Chris Adams, the
Knights
continued their winning ways.
It came down to the nitty-gritty in Game 6, but the
O.R.P. Knights
prevailed. They had guaranteed themselves an overall third place victory on the evening. But the chaos was far from over ...
The finals of the winners-bracket was perhaps the most emotionally draining game of the night. The
Knights
had yet to lose a single match and winning this 7th game would have secured their spot in the ultimate final round. Facing the powerful and agile team
Skillz that Thrillz
, the
Knights
would go on to suffer their first defeat. Because of the crushing defeat, the
Knights
battled the winners of the losers-bracket, with the opportunity of a rematch in the ultimate finals against
Skillz that Thrillz
. This game didn't come without a fight though, as Chris Adams remained with two nasty, hungry opponents. But the experience of the 24 year-old proved the deciding factor, as Chris capped Game 8 and sent the
O.R.P. Knights
straight to the finals of the entire tournament.
The Finals:
The 7-1
O.R.P. Knights
vs. The 8-0
Skillz that Thrillz
The
Knights
were in a must-win situation, with a 1st place victory by way of defeating
Skillz that Thrillz
in two consecutive matches.
Skillz that Thrillz
had already defeated the determined
Knights
, and certainly had the upper hand going into the finale.
In what was another outstanding, chaotic match-up,
Skillz that Thrillz
defeated the popular
O.R.P. Knights
taking home the gold. Congratulations are certainly in order to the standout team, as their 1st place win didn't come without a fight.
But what an effort by the
Knights
taking
2nd place
out of an astounding 52 teams. Heading into the tournament, few would have thought the success of the
Knights
would have reached the heights it did.
The frowns of 1st place failure were turned upside down by the wild cheering squad and the overall effort and desire by the players themselves. If not for the support of friends and family in attendance, things may have been different.
The celebration of the well-deserved 2nd place victory concluded with a classic: Applebee's half-price appetizers.
The Cheering Section!
In support for both teams was a rowdy cheering section comprised of Lauren Stopa, Valerie Winston, Meredith Lewis, Rob Avakian, Melissa Kerr, and Lauren Winston. A special thanks to each, looking on for the entire duration of the tournament.
Both teams themselves also feuled the fun, applauding the efforts of each other and other adversaries.
Thanks!
Again, thanks go out to the cheering sqaud who made the event as fun and entertaining as possible.
Without question, both "Sputz" and Ryan McCrorey deserve thanks as their company, Ahern Printing, sponsored the
O.R.P. Knights
. The admissions fee as well as the uniforms were paid for by Ahern.
And also, thanks to everyone who captured pictures or took video.
Unquestionably, one of the most amazing nights in the one year-plus history of dodgeball!
>>

body_html:
"I don't even know where to begin really. A surreal night, one unlike any other. This tournament brought out feelings in me only comparable to the ten-events. After all was said and done, you come away with more than just a trophy, but friends for the rest of your life. For 5 hours, life's roadblocks cease to exist."
- JOHN TRONOLONE

-- 52 teams, 1 goal: win the first-ever Toms River Tournament. Double Elimination!
Pretty simple right? WRONG.

The chills run up your spine, the hair on your neck stands up, the adrenaline pumps ...
You're probably getting those very feelings just thinking about it.

The R.A.T.S.
Formed in just 4 short days, co-captained by the dominant female duo Sara DeCuir and Diana DiBuccio, The R.A.T.S. were ready, willing, and able to come out on top in this massive 52-team war.
Cap. Sara DeCuir
Cap. Diana DiBuccio
Mike Edwards
Derek Carty [not pictured]
Alison Bertsch
Mike Butler
Sascha Basista
Jack Mess
Lenny Herrera
Joey Smalls*.

*Replaced Grant Cornero, who was unable to attend due to a conflicting work schedule.


The first round match-up turned out to be a show-stealer. It wasn't easy however as one-by-one, The R.A.T.S. were disposed of, leaving Sascha Basista fighting against a pack of wolves - alone. But just when things looked grim, the dodging specialties in young Basista began to come out, with all ears and eyes positioned on Court 2. With the crowd solidly behind him, Sascha fended off a good number of opponents before going down. Much credit deserved to the young lion who was greeted by a well-deserved ovation upon returning to the stands.

With one loss already recorded, winning this next match would decide the fate of The R.A.T.S. Unfortuantely, Round 2 mirrored that of their first encounter, as within 3 minutes, Derek Carty and Mike Butler were all that remained of the red and black attack. Once Derek went down, it was all up to Butler who has proven time and again to be a top dog. After a gutsy effort, Butler was taken out by the relentless onslaught of his opponents.

A terrific, fearless showing for The R.A.T.S. as a team that faced adversity before gametime made an impact the only way they know how. None of the team members have anything to be ashamed of.

The O.R.P. Knights
An all-star team, co-captained by Ryan McCrorey and Mike "Sputz" Krott, with one purpose ... to win.
Cap. Ryan McCrorey
Cap. Mike "Sputz" Krott
Chris Burke
Justin Pierce
Kevin Adams
Kevin Fitzpatrick
John Tronolone
Chris Adams
Kevin Megill Jr.
Tom Adams

Smaller boundries, softer painball-sized dodge balls, among pages and pages of rules unaccustomed to the weekly dodgeball fan created heavy turmoil before the getgo. But despite being taken out of their element, the O.R.P. Knights were nothing short of dominant.

The initial round witnessed an impressive showing from one Tom Adams, eliminating 40% of his opposition, a game that eventually ended with a lucky footshot from John Tronolone. The O.R.P. Knights were moving up the ladder of success.

One after another, the Knights looked unstoppable, defeating the tourny's best sqauds. Though eliminations came fast and furious, through it all, the group remained strong. The brackets became increasingly smaller, with the Knights still on the board.

Come the fourth and fifth rounds, the butterflies remained, each match becoming more crucial than the last. But somehow, especially with expertise of the legendary Chris Adams, the Knights continued their winning ways.

It came down to the nitty-gritty in Game 6, but the O.R.P. Knights prevailed. They had guaranteed themselves an overall third place victory on the evening. But the chaos was far from over ...

The finals of the winners-bracket was perhaps the most emotionally draining game of the night. The Knights had yet to lose a single match and winning this 7th game would have secured their spot in the ultimate final round. Facing the powerful and agile team Skillz that Thrillz, the Knights would go on to suffer their first defeat. Because of the crushing defeat, the Knights battled the winners of the losers-bracket, with the opportunity of a rematch in the ultimate finals against Skillz that Thrillz. This game didn't come without a fight though, as Chris Adams remained with two nasty, hungry opponents. But the experience of the 24 year-old proved the deciding factor, as Chris capped Game 8 and sent the O.R.P. Knights straight to the finals of the entire tournament.

The Finals: The 7-1 O.R.P. Knights vs. The 8-0 Skillz that Thrillz
The Knights were in a must-win situation, with a 1st place victory by way of defeating Skillz that Thrillz in two consecutive matches. Skillz that Thrillz had already defeated the determined Knights, and certainly had the upper hand going into the finale.

In what was another outstanding, chaotic match-up, Skillz that Thrillz defeated the popular O.R.P. Knights taking home the gold. Congratulations are certainly in order to the standout team, as their 1st place win didn't come without a fight.

But what an effort by the Knights taking 2nd place out of an astounding 52 teams. Heading into the tournament, few would have thought the success of the Knights would have reached the heights it did.

The frowns of 1st place failure were turned upside down by the wild cheering squad and the overall effort and desire by the players themselves. If not for the support of friends and family in attendance, things may have been different.

The celebration of the well-deserved 2nd place victory concluded with a classic: Applebee's half-price appetizers.


The Cheering Section!
In support for both teams was a rowdy cheering section comprised of Lauren Stopa, Valerie Winston, Meredith Lewis, Rob Avakian, Melissa Kerr, and Lauren Winston. A special thanks to each, looking on for the entire duration of the tournament.

Both teams themselves also feuled the fun, applauding the efforts of each other and other adversaries.

Thanks!
Again, thanks go out to the cheering sqaud who made the event as fun and entertaining as possible.

Without question, both "Sputz" and Ryan McCrorey deserve thanks as their company, Ahern Printing, sponsored the O.R.P. Knights. The admissions fee as well as the uniforms were paid for by Ahern.

And also, thanks to everyone who captured pictures or took video.

Unquestionably, one of the most amazing nights in the one year-plus history of dodgeball!
